entry.title: Let's geek out!
entry.content:
I was looking at this year’s Google I/O website, please take a look at it. This is the design I really love: Simple, flat, creative and modern! My hope every web designer/developer get inspired by this website in the future for better quality!

If you notice in the second screen of the website, you’ll find a nice photo and some text that is being written continuously on top of it with some cool words: Let’s geek out, Let’s hack, Let’s reboot, Let’s do this, etc.

I personally liked it so much and found it original, so today, we’re going to recreate it with HTML, Javascript and CSS3. This is going to be very simple, even if you don’t have a lot of knowledge in JS or CSS3 you can easily follow the tutorial and understand how it is working.

Let’s start!

First of all, we have to define the structure of our HTML page. We should put a background image, inside it we have a static text (Let’s), next to it a dynamic text (geek out) and finally a blinking cursor. So we will have the following structure:

<section class="background">
	<section class="text">
		<span class="static-word">Let's</span>
		<span id="type-out__word">(dynamic text)</span>
		<span class="type-out__beam blink"> </span>
	</section>
</section>

This is our file structure, very simple! Now we need to add a script in order to manipulate this document and add our typing effect to it. I’ll first explain how does it work. First, we will define an array of words that are going to be written in the dynamic text containet span. Then, we will use Javascript timing methods setInterval() and setTimeout() for the delays, so the text will not appear at once, but we’ll simulate the writing instead.

Javascript’s setInterval() method takes two arguments, a callback and a time interval just like this:

setInterval(function() { //do stuff here; }, 1000); //interval in milliseconds

This means that anything you put in the //do stuff here; section will be executed repeatedly every 1 second. If you want to stop this execution, then you’ll have to call the clearInterval() method, by giving the name of your setInterval() method as a parameter just like this:

var myIntervalMethod = setInterval(function() { //do stuff here; }, 1000); //interval in milliseconds
clearInterval(myIntervalMethod);

The other timing method that we’re going to use is the setTimeout() method which works like setInterval() but it executes the callback method only once. It’s like you’re telling your brwoser: Okay, please wait 1000 milliseconds, then execute this callback method.

You can read more about Javascript’s timing methods by following THIS link.

So here is our Javascript code to simulate the typing:

//First, we get our span in which we're going to display dynamic text.
var word_holder = document.getElementById("type-out__word");

//We define our array of words that we want to display, you can add as many words as you want.
var words = ['geek out', 'break stuff', 'reboot', 'hack', 'grab a drink', 'do this', 'create', 'learn', 'invent'];

//word_index is the index in the array of the word being typed.
var word_index = 0;

//char_index is the index in the word of the character being typed.
var char_index = 0;

//we tell the browser to execute writeText() method every 50 milliseconds.
myWriteInterval = setInterval(function() { writeText() }, 50);

//we define writeText() method responsible of typing characters in the dynamic text span.
function writeText() {
	//we add the character in char_index position of the word_index word to our span's innnerHTML.
	word_holder.innerHTML += words[word_index][char_index];
	//increment the char_index to write the next character during the next call of the method
	char_index++;
	//if we've just types the last character of a word, increment word_index and call stopInterval() to wait a little bit.
	if (char_index == words[word_index].length) {
		word_index++;
		char_index = 0;
		stopInterval();
	};
	//if we've just wrote the last word of the array, we start over.
	if (word_index == words.length) {
		word_index = 0;
	};
}

//we define our stopInterval() method responsible of pausing the typing a little bit and then restarting it.
function stopInterval() {
	//clearInterval() stops the actual execution of myWriteInterval function.
	clearInterval(myWriteInterval);

	//here we call setTimeout() in order to wait 3 seconds before calling myWriteInterval again to fire up the typing of the next word.
	setTimeout(function() { 
		//we clear the content of our span.
		word_holder.innerHTML = "";
		myWriteInterval = setInterval(function() { writeText() }, 50); 
	}, 3000);
}

If you execute this code now, it should display “Let’s ” plus a word from the array with typing being simulated and all. This is perfect. But you will notice that it just doesn’t look like Google’s one, ours is ugly! Of course, here is when CSS comes into the game :)

In order for our page to look more beautiful, we will add the following styling to it, nothing special.

<style>
@import url(http://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Roboto:100,400);

.type-out__beam{
	display:inline-block;
	margin-bottom:-0.12em;
	width:0.04545em;
	line-height:1;
	min-width:1px;
	background-color:#fee94e;
	vertical-align:baseline
}

.static-word {
	color: white;
}

.background {
	font-family: 'Roboto', sans-serif;
	font-weight:  100;
	font-size: 4.44444em;
	line-height: 1.125;
	color: #fee94e;
	background-image:url("https://www.google.com/events/io/images/photos/experience-1400.jpg");
	height:  500px;
	padding-top: 400px;
	margin: 0;
}

.text {
	text-align: center;
	font-weight: 400;
}
</style>

Put all together and you should have the following result:

You will tell me now that the cursor is not blinking like Google’s one! You are wright, because we haven’t add any CSS3 animations yet. Add the following code into your style:

@-webkit-keyframes blink{
	0%{opacity:1}
	50%{opacity:0}
}
@-moz-keyframes blink{
	0%{opacity:1}
	50%{opacity:0}
}
@-ms-keyframes blink{
	0%{opacity:1}
	50%{opacity:0}
}
@keyframes blink{
	0%{opacity:1}
	50%{opacity:0}
}

.type-out__beam.blink{
	-webkit-animation:blink 1s step-end infinite;
	-moz-animation:blink 1s step-end infinite;
	-o-animation:blink 1s step-end infinite;
	animation:blink 1s step-end infinite
}

This will tell the browser to look for a tag with .blink class and apply the animation with the name blink to it. This animation has been defined above. Basically, it sets the opacity of the object to 1 in 0% keyframe and to 0 in 50% keyframe. That’s all.

Now when you put all of this together you should see a very nice typing with styles and everything, exactly like Google’s one and here is the demo :

Let's  

That’s all for today, hope this article was helpful for you to understand the basics of CSS styling and Javascript tuming methods. Thanks to my friend Ikbal Corleone for helping me out with CSS stuff ;)

If you have encountred any problem and this is not working for some reasons, here is the complete code, just copy and past it into a file named typing.html and open it with your browser (Chrome, Mozilla, Opera or Safari).

Complete working code

typing.html :

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<title>Type out!</title>
<style type="text/css">
@import url(http://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Roboto:100,400);

@-webkit-keyframes blink{
	0%{opacity:1}
	50%{opacity:0}
}
@-moz-keyframes blink{
	0%{opacity:1}
	50%{opacity:0}
}
@-ms-keyframes blink{
	0%{opacity:1}
	50%{opacity:0}
}
@keyframes blink{
	0%{opacity:1}
	50%{opacity:0}
}
.type-out__beam{
	display:inline-block;
	margin-bottom:-0.12em;
	width:0.04545em;
	line-height:1;
	min-width:1px;
	background-color:#fee94e;
	vertical-align:baseline
}
.type-out__beam.blink{
	-webkit-animation:blink 1s step-end infinite;
	-moz-animation:blink 1s step-end infinite;
	-o-animation:blink 1s step-end infinite;
	animation:blink 1s step-end infinite
}

.static-word {
	color: white;
}

.background {
	font-family: 'Roboto', sans-serif;
	font-weight:  100;
	font-size: 4.44444em;
	line-height: 1.125;
	color: #fee94e;
	background-image:url("https://www.google.com/events/io/images/photos/experience-1400.jpg");
	height:  500px;
	padding-top: 400px;
	margin: 0;
}

.text {
	text-align: center;
	font-weight: 400;
}
</style>
</head>
<body>
<section class="background">
	<section class="text">
		<span class="static-word">Let's </span>
		<span id="type-out__word" class='type-out__word'></span>
		<span class="type-out__beam blink"> </span>
	</section>
</section>
<script type="text/javascript">
	var word_holder = document.getElementById("type-out__word");
	var words = ['geek out', 'break stuff', 'reboot', 'hack', 'grab a drink', 'do this', 'create', 'learn', 'invent'];
	var word_index = 0;
	var char_index = 0;
	myWriteInterval = setInterval(function() { writeText() }, 50);
	function writeText() {
		word_holder.innerHTML += words[word_index][char_index];
		char_index++;
		if (char_index == words[word_index].length) {
			word_index++;
			char_index = 0;
			stopInterval();
		};
		if (word_index == words.length) {
			word_index = 0;
		};
	}
	function stopInterval() {
		clearInterval(myWriteInterval);
		setTimeout(function() { 
			word_holder.innerHTML = "";
			myWriteInterval = setInterval(function() { writeText() }, 50); 
		}, 3000);
	}
</script>
</body>
</html>

entry.title: Gmail Shelfie, revealed!
entry.content:
Today, is April 1st and usual Google has announced many April fools.

I personally liked the Gmail Shelfie, it’s just cool. Each time you open your email you could see some selfies (sometimes pretty ones :p). It seemed weird to me, why should Google add such feature to Gmail just for April 1st ??

So I fired up my console I clicked the famous “Inspect Element” on the images to see how it is working, I figured out that they’re just using static images and there is no such a service behind. So let’s discover all the 27 beautiful high resolution slefies that Google made to let us seem stupid by believing it was a new addition to Gmail!

Photo 00

Photo 01

Photo 02

Photo 03

Photo 04

Photo 05

Photo 06

Photo 07

Photo 08

Photo 09

Photo 10

Photo 11

Photo 12

Photo 13

Photo 26

I’ll let you find the link between these images ;)

entry.title: An introduction to Google App Engine
entry.content:
Nowadays, everyone is going cloud, writing applications has never been easier when you just focus on them, no need to think about the infrastructure, the operating system, platforms’ versions, etc. One of the most powerful cloud platforms is GCP : Google Cloud Platform.

Today we’re going to talk about Google App Engine, which is part of GCP and allows you to write scalable applications and deploy them to Google servers in minutes. You can read more about Google App Engine here, and follow a very nice tutorial here. Basically, apps that run on App Engine are written in Python, Java, Go and PHP. In this tutorial we’re going to talk only about Python.

When you write a GAE application with python, you have your .py files that are server side, and your .html, .js and .css files that are client side. You also have your app.yaml file which contains the global config of your application, it’s there where you put the name of your project, version, used libraries, etc.

In order for your app to show in web browsers, it should contain RequestHandlers which are simply python classes that extend webapp2.RequestHandler class. Typically, a RequesHandler class contains a get() and a post() method to respond to HTTP GET and HTTP POST calls.

Here is a simple example of a RequestHandler that shows a text in the browser:

import webapp2

class MainHandler(webapp2.RequestHandler):
	def get(self):
		self.response.write('You have just wrote your first GAE application!')

As simple as that, if we run this application, we’ll get the following message on the browser:

Now, let’s suppose that you need to show more beautiful pages to your users, with your own custom style and images and everything that people want to see, in this case, you need to use separate html files and then render them with values that you want to display to your users. We do this with jinja2 and here is a very simple demo:

import webapp2
import jinja2
import os

JINJA_ENVIRONMENT = jinja2.Environment(
  loader=jinja2.FileSystemLoader(os.path.dirname(__file__)),
  extensions=['jinja2.ext.autoescape'])

our_beautiful_page = JINJA_ENVIRONMENT.get_template('home.html')

class MainHandler(webapp2.RequestHandler):
	def get(self):
		self.response.write(our_beautiful_page.render())

This will display home.html on the browser.

If you want to send values from your class to your customized HTML page, you can do it like this:

1- our_beautiful_page.html:

<h1 style="color: red;"> Welcome mister: {{name}}</h1>

2- main.py:

self.response.write(our_beautiful_page.render(name = "John"))

If you execute this code, you’ll get the following result on your browser:

Complete working code:

1- app.yaml file:

application: my-first-gae-app
version: 1
runtime: python27
api_version: 1
threadsafe: yes

handlers:
- url: /favicon\.ico
  static_files: favicon.ico
  upload: favicon\.ico

- url: .*
  script: main.app

libraries:
- name: webapp2
  version: "2.5.2"
- name: jinja2
  version: latest

2- main.py file:

import webapp2
import jinja2
import os

JINJA_ENVIRONMENT = jinja2.Environment(
  loader=jinja2.FileSystemLoader(os.path.dirname(__file__)),
  extensions=['jinja2.ext.autoescape'])

our_beautiful_page = JINJA_ENVIRONMENT.get_template('home.html')

class MainHandler(webapp2.RequestHandler):
	def get(self):
		self.response.write(our_beautiful_page.render(name = "John"))

app = webapp2.WSGIApplication([
    ('/', MainHandler)
], debug=True)

3- our_beautiful_page.html file:

<html>
<head>
<title>My first GAE application!</title>
</head>
<body>

<h1 style="color: red;"> Welcome mister: {{name}}</h1>

</body>
</html>

That’s all for now, hope to see you in the next tutorial and learn more stuff together,

Meanwhile, you can see this video in order to get a better vision about Google Cloud Platform.

entry.title: 7 things I learnt from NYUAD Hackathon 2013 !
entry.content:
Last week, I have been honored by New York University of Abu Dhabi to participate in an annual event which is the International Hackathon in its 2nd edition. There were many students, mentors and judges from all over the world, I met people from the US, Canada, Mexico, Brazil, Denmark, Tunisia, Morocco, Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Sri Lanka and India.

The aim of the hackathon is to gather all these skillful people in one place and build some cool products for social good in MENA region. All of us were brainstorming to select the best sixteen ideas and then everyone joined the team he wants to work with. This step is called “Ready, Set, Pitch!” It’s really crazy when you find yourself working with people you just met and you believe that after only three days, you are going to show something publicly and that it should be working!!

I will try in this article to highlight the most important things I learnt from this amazing and unique experience. So let’s start.

1. Be tolerant:

During the event, there have been students from different countries and continents this means different cultures and religions, it is really nice how they worked together in the same teams without any conflicts and complexes. So one thing to learn is that you can work with people that do not have certainly the same culture like you and do not share the same religious or political views. When you are working for the same goal you can reach it together, you just have to be tolerant and accept the other as it is, just focus on your subject.

2. Believe in yourself:

In the beginning of the hackathon when we chose our projects and we started the work I told myself that it’s really hard for me to achieve the work in just three days and because I changed the team, It has been a little difficult for me to integrate this new team. But after that, I realized that when you define your tasks in a clear way, you can work on a small idea and move to the second one when you finish it. So you can think big while acting on small pieces and assemble them at the end. After three days only, I was surprised when I saw that we finished the main skeleton of the app, it was really awesome.

3. #AgeIsJustANumber:

At first when we met in the big room for discussing and brainstorming ideas, I saw a kid between us, instantly, I thought he was a son of someone or something like that.. Than I realized that he was a participant when he started talking about windows 8, windows phone 8 and stuff.. I was just surprised! He joined our table and I talked to him, he is a 14 years old programmer from India and his name is Gautam! We’ve been in the same team for the two next days. This guy taught me that age is really just a number, that everyone has the ability to start programming at an earlier stage, kids in my country are not used to.. They’re just afraid of.

4. Shut up and go build something useful:

I have participated in many events in Algeria before, events like StartUp weekend, BootCamps and many training sessions. The difference with this one (NYUAD Hackathon) that it’s based on the results, I mean that your job is evaluated by your demo, there is not much talk and long speeches with theoretical aspects and business stuff and so on.. It’s all about code, teamwork and vision. You have to have a great idea first, than you start working on small parts of it to ensure that you’ll have something to demonstrate after three days. There is no need to a long speech and business plans and stuff without any product at the end.

5. Never give up:

Another thing I learnt from this Hackathon is that one should never give up when it comes to doing something that he loves. I have been with a team at the beginning than the organizers said that our team was too big so I changed the team, then, in the second day, we completely changed the idea.. I have to confess that at some moment I lost confidence, I was like : “what the hell is happening to me?” because time is moving on. So we decided to keep the two ideas and divided tasks, we wanted to incorporate a game inside our app, but in the third day we realized that it was not evident to port a windows phone 7 game to windows 8! We decided then to create our own new game.. It was so stressful but it was really funny because the team I was with is the most awesome team I have ever been with!

6. Improve your English! You’ll need it:

If there is one thing I could advise my peers in Algeria, is to learn and practice English. I am telling you that, because I personally found some difficulties especially at the first time, because here in Algeria we study in french so it’s difficult for someone who has never talked in English before to express himself and his ideas with people that does not understand French. So, please, speak in English! Even if you think that you are very bad but just go on and try to practice it with your friends and everyone who can understand you.. or cannot! Because french is not going to help you outside France and some other countries but English is boundless, you can use it everywhere.. Trust me, Start today !

7. Don’t be too serious! Have fun !

Here is the list of all the projects! (4.)

Finally, I want to thank all of the organizers for making this opportunity happen in our region, we really need such initiatives! So let me thank prof. Sana’ Odeh for the amazing efforts she did for us, all the mentors especially David Tomczyk and Arnaud Sahuguet for their precious help. Looking forward to seeing you again next year.

entry.title: This blog, what and why?
entry.content:
I’ve been thinking about my first blog post since two days, what the hell should it be about? I had many ideas, but i realized that the best thing to talk about as a first Article is the reason of creating this blog and what will it be about; So could know whether it interests you or not.

Well, I always wanted to discuss and share ideas with other people and I’m actually doing it through social networks such as Google+, Facebook, Twitter, Skype and others. But the problem with these social networks is that the information that we write there is not easily found, easily linked to or searchable by other people, it remains in the website’s servers but we can not benefit from it after some moments. Unlike blogs, who are generally ‘public’, ‘searchable’, ‘relevant’ and ‘topics-oriented’. I’ve been inspired by Scott Hanselman’s blog post about blogging, he said: “Write a few blog posts a week, with useful content, consistently, for ten years. Then write some more”.

The other reason that motivates me to create this blog is my participation in two conferences last week about Arabic content on the internet, this first one was held in Laghouat on Dec 18th, the second one in Algiers on Dec 20th, both of them were celebrating the Arabic Web Days initiative. I talked during these two events about the State of the Arabic content on the WEB and i gave some solution to increase it, one of the solutions I gave was “Creating relevant blogs”, I realized then that even me I do not have a blog, Shame on me you’d say !

To give you a quick view about what this blog is all about, mainly, I’m going to write about technical staff (informatics to be clear), an important part of them will be in Arabic. Also, I will write about my personal projects like for example the story Halim and I are writing (في صحراء أُسياط). And of course I’ll write about our beloved group which is GDG Algiers (Google Developer Group Algiers) and its activities, highlighting the great experience we’re having together.

I think this is enough for a first post, I hope this hasn’t made you bored and thanks for your time, that’s all. :)
